images.caption: Figure 1:An overview of our data collection pipeline. The pipeline consists of three distinct stages: 1)Stage #1 Sequence Generation: for each image, a series of atomic instructions is produced; 2)Stage #2 Simplification: each fundamental instruction is refined to eliminate extraneous details, preserving only the essential description of the editing process; 3)Stage #3 Instruction Compounding: several atomic instructions are integrated into one comprehensive instruction.
Figure 2:The distribution of atomic instructions among 9 operation categories. The arc thickness between two categories shows the number of adjacent instructions from these two categories.
Figure 3:An illustration of 24 types of atomic editing operations in 9 categories.
Figure 4:Examples of evaluation results for Instruction Following and Identity Preservation.
Figure 5:Examples of evaluation results for Perceptual Quality.
Figure 6:Relationship between per-sample variance and the number of measurements

Figure 12:Qualitative results of sequential editing with and without Best-of-4444with OmniGen on real input images. The instructions are the same ones inFig.8(a). Qualitative results with more models are shown in the supplementaryFig.20.

Figure 13:Direct and Sequential Editing results w/ Best-of-NùëÅNitalic_Nof open-source models on real input images. The complexity level is atC8subscriptùê∂8C_{8}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 8 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. This shows that Best-of-NùëÅNitalic_Ncan improveI‚Å¢FùêºùêπIFitalic_I italic_FandP‚Å¢QùëÉùëÑPQitalic_P italic_Qespecially for sequential editing. However, sequential editing with Best-of-NùëÅNitalic_Ncan still barely surpass direct editing without Best-of-NùëÅNitalic_N.

Figure 16:Additional qualitative results with direct editing on real-life images. As instruction complexity increases, the gap between open-source and proprietary models widens, and both Identity Preservation and Perceptual Quality decline, with variable effects on Instruction Following across models. SeeSec.5.2for more details.

Figure 17:Additional qualitative results with direct editing on synthetic images. As instruction complexity increases, the gap between open-source and proprietary models widens, and both Identity Preservation and Perceptual Quality decline, with variable effects on Instruction Following across models. SeeSec.5.2for more details.

Figure 18:Additional qualitative results with sequential editing on real-life images. Identity Preservation and Perceptual Quality, degrade as visual artifacts and distortions increase with more intermediate steps. Even advanced proprietary models,i.e.Imagen3 and SeedEdit, struggle to maintain element identity and quality in output images. More in-depth analysis is inSec.5.4.1.

Figure 19:Additional qualitative results with sequential editing on synthetic images. Identity Preservation and Perceptual Quality, degrade as visual artifacts and distortions increase with more intermediate steps. Even advanced proprietary models,i.e.Imagen3 and SeedEdit, struggle to maintain element identity and quality in output images. More in-depth analysis is inSec.5.4.1.

Figure 20:Qualitative results with sequential editing with Best-of-4 on real-life images. Identity Preservation and Perceptual Quality of sequential editing improve significantly with Best-of-4. Refer toSec.5.4.2for more detailed discussions.

Figure 21:More real-life images edited with aC8subscriptùê∂8C_{8}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 8 end_POSTSUBSCRIPTinstruction by GPT-4o. Outputs from GPT-4o severely lose the realistic style. Refer toSec.5.3for a detailed discussion.
